bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, October 5, 1927

div1.p: Kean informs Agramonte that he would like to publish his recollections of the yellow fever experiments in "The Military Surgeon."

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, October 5, 1927
div1.opener:
Pers file
Keep
IOK
5 October, 1927.
Dr. Aristides Agramonte,
University of Havana,
Havana, Cuba.
My dear Dr. Agramonte:
div1.p:
Major Callender brought down to me yesterday, and I have read
with the greatest interest, the little pamphlet which you sent him giv-
ing an account of the details of the Reed Yellow Fever Board. It is
especially interesting and valuable on account of the details and the
accurate statement of your share in the work. This letter I had only
known from the somewhat jaundiced information given me by Carroll. This
pamphlet is, I think, very little known in the United States. With my
great interest in the matter, I had never seen it before and am sorry
that you did not have my name on your mailing list. Would you object
to my republishing it in The Military Surgeon where it will reach a very
important section of the Medical Profession?

It would, in my opinion, add much to the value of it if you
would state somewhat fully your experiments in attempting to transmit
yellow fever to animals and the conclusive negative results; and follow
this with a brief epitome of Noguchi's work and Sellard's demonstration
that his causative organism is not that of yellow fever but of infectious
jaundice. I think you could do this with very little work and it would
certainly be a very valuable and interesting paper.

If it is reprinted, I would like to make one very small and
unimportant correction which is the statement that Captain Stark was
the Chief Surgeon. Of course as you know I was the Chief Surgeon and
at the time of the outbreak of yellow fever at Pinar del Rio he was
occupying my desk because I was absent for a month's sick leave in the
States while recovering from my attack of yellow fever in June.

It was a pleasure to see you last Monday and I wish I could
have seen more of you and had a good talk.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired
Editor. JRK/W
